hints.content:
There are $\blueD{3}$ periods.

The Rangers score $\greenD{6}$ total goals.

[[☃ image 1]]

What is the $\purpleC{\text{size of the groups}}$?

options.alt: A tape diagram with 2 tapes of equal lengths. The first tape is labeled 6 and the second tape with 3 equal parts each labeled with a question mark. A curved bracket across the bottom and the width of the second tape is labeled with the words 3 equal groups. !

hints.content:
We can write this as a multiplication problem. 

$\blueD{\text{ number of groups}}\times\purpleC{\text{size of the group}}= \greenD{\text{ total}}$

So, $\blueD{3}\times\purpleC{\text{?}} = \greenD{6}$

We can also write this as a division problem. 

$\greenD{\text{total}}\div\blueD{\text{ number of groups}}=\purpleC{\text{ size of the groups}}$

So, $\greenD{6}\div \blueD{3}=\purpleC{\text{?}}$

The equations that would help us find out how many goals the Rangers scored in each period are:  

 - $\blueD{3}\times\purpleC{\text{?}} = \greenD{6}$
 - $\greenD{6}\div \blueD{3}=\purpleC{\text{?}}$

question.content:
What a great game!  The Rangers scored $6$ goals in the hockey game.  They scored the same number of goals in each of the $3$ periods.  

**Which equations would help us find out how many goals the Rangers scored in each period?**

[[☃ radio 1]]
